body_html:
It looks like the failure is legit; there's a test that's asserting that stderr matches a specific string, and it's failing because of items printed out by the AWS client initialization.

This exposes a problem with greedy loading of the client: We'll see errors printed out in environments without valid credentials on startup. I'll make the client lazily-initialized, which should fix the test, and keep the errors from showing up unless you're trying to use S3.
body_text:
It looks like the failure is legit; there's a test that's asserting that stderr matches a specific string, and it's failing because of items printed out by the AWS client initialization.
This exposes a problem with greedy loading of the client: We'll see errors printed out in environments without valid credentials on startup. I'll make the client lazily-initialized, which should fix the test, and keep the errors from showing up unless you're trying to use S3.
body:
It looks like the failure is legit; there's a test that's asserting that stderr matches a specific string, and it's failing because of items printed out by the AWS client initialization.

This exposes a problem with greedy loading of the client: We'll see errors printed out in environments without valid credentials on startup. I'll make the client lazily-initialized, which should fix the test, and keep the errors from showing up unless you're trying to use S3.
